primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The human journey is defined as a universal 'search' for fulfillment, identity, and comfort, which finds its ultimate destination in 'seeing' or 'getting hold of' Jesus.

subject.identificatie: The Human Seeker (The 'Greeks', the Hearer, the Preacher)
tekstueel_bewijs: All of life is a search
we search for some serene place
they decided that he [Philip] ought to be a good point of contact

object.identificatie: Jesus (as a Vision, a Helper, or a Solution)

tekstueel_bewijs: It is a God-given attribute of our humanity to want to count
Something inside of them remained unfulfilled
he or she will receive one hundredfold in this life
I will give you the desires of your heart
Philip... was aptly suited to be the intermediary
For somebody who is hurt, he is the great Healer

tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: While death is mentioned, the primary focus is on the 'sadness' and 'hurt' of the seeker rather than a cosmic or ontological enmity with God.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The preacher's personal struggle with vanity and the use of the pulpit.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Preacher
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The preacher uses his own 'search' for a pure ministry as a model for the congregation's search.

actantieel_schema_visualisatie.zender_naar_ontvanger: Innate Desire → Jesus → The Fulfilled Self

voorbeelden_god_subject: the Lord has put in us the desire
I [Jesus] will give you the desires of your heart
voorbeelden_mens_subject: we search for some serene place
we ought to bring our ambitions to Jesus
take hold of him right there

voorbeelden: We ought to bring our ambitions before the Lord
Do not dazzle us with your knowledge
get hold of him right there

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon is a 'Recruitment' narrative. It focuses on awakening and directing human desire (Vouloir) toward Jesus as the solution to human lack.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: From the lack of S1 (Searching) through the fear of S2 (Death) to the instrumental use of Jesus to regain S1.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Jesus is presented as the one who validates human ambition and comforts human grief, effectively neutralizing S2.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Moderate; death is a 'sadness' rather than a 'judgment'.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: While the sermon uses high Christological language, the actantial subject is consistently the human 'seeker.' Jesus is the Object to be 'gotten hold of' or the Helper who facilitates human success and comfort.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: Whatever it is about the Lord that attracts you, take hold of that.
We ought to bring our ambitions to Jesus.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: Thy sins are forgiven. Your slate is wiped clean.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: The Greeks and Michelangelo are used as models for human persistence and vision.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: Instead of 'The Greeks searched for Jesus,' focus on 'Jesus came to the hour where he would be glorified for the Greeks.'

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Empowerment of the will; the hearer feels responsible for 'carrying' their life to Jesus.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Synergism where human initiative triggers divine response.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The 'Search' metaphor provides strong thematic unity but collapses the distinction between natural desire and spiritual rebirth.
spanning_punten: The transition from 'ambition' to 'forgiveness' feels like a category error.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: Look at him, and hear him say to you, 'You are the light of the world.'

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The sermon assumes the hearer already has the 'Vouloir' (will) and only needs the 'Object' (Jesus).

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Sin is 'breaking faith' with the 'royal' part of oneself, rather than total depravity.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon is a narrative of human pursuit where Jesus is the prize. The 'engine' is human desire (Vouloir-faire).

subject_herpositionering.huidige_probleem: The hearer is the one searching; Jesus is passive until 'found'.
subject_herpositionering.voorgestelde_herpositionering: Jesus as the Seeker who finds the lost.
subject_herpositionering.voorbeeld_revisie: Instead of 'We search for Jesus,' use 'Jesus has been searching for you since before you knew his name.'

identificatie_herstel.voorgestelde_identificatie: Hearer as the 'Dead Man' (Lazarus context of John 12).
identificatie_herstel.strategie: Emphasize that we do not 'see' Jesus by our own power, but he reveals himself to the blind.

modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Focus on how Jesus gives the power to see, rather than our desire to see.

tegenstander_intensivering.voorgestelde_intensivering: Death as the 'Last Enemy' that only a Crucified God can defeat.
tegenstander_intensivering.theologische_rationale: Without a heavy opponent, grace becomes a therapeutic 'comfort' rather than a rescue.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: Salvation (God finds us) → Ethics (We serve because we are found).

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: The sermon is rhetorically masterful and deeply moving, but structurally anthropocentric. Shifting the verbs from 'our search' to 'His finding' would transform this from a recruitment speech into a Gospel proclamation.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: Rhetorically, the 'search' theme is brilliant; actantially, it makes the human the hero.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis would note that in John 12, the Greeks' arrival triggers Jesus' talk of his death (the grain of wheat), which the sermon omits.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas reveals that 'Jesus' functions here as a 'Helper' to human 'Ambition' rather than the Sovereign Subject of the narrative.

volledige_subject_lijst: You have a sphere of influence
appendices.notities: The sermon relies heavily on the 'Vouloir' (will/desire) of the hearer to bridge the gap to the Divine.
